This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question.

(12 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

A hydrogen atom can be modeled as a single electron in a circular orbit around a stationary proton. Some properties of the atom can be explained by treating the proton and electron as particles and using classical mechanics and electrostatics. Other properties can be explained using the standing wave model of the electron.

(a) The energy of a hydrogen atom in state <math alttext="n" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="E sub n equals, negative, open parenthesis, 13.6 electron volts, close parenthesis, divided by n squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>13.6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>eV</mtext></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>/</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

i. Determine the energy of a hydrogen atom in the <math alttext="n equals 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> state.

ii. The electric potential energy of a hydrogen atom in the <math alttext="n equals 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> state is <math alttext="negative 3.02 electron volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3.02</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext> eV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> . Using classical mechanics and electrostatics, calculate the orbital radius of the electron for this state in meters.

iii. Calculate the kinetic energy of the electron when the hydrogen atom is in the <math alttext="n equals 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> state.
iv. Calculate the speed of the electron when the atom is in the <math alttext="n equals 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> state.

(b) The standing wave model uses the de Broglie wavelength of the electron.

i. Calculate the de Broglie wavelength of the electron in the <math alttext="n equals 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> state of a hydrogen atom.
ii. Describe the relationship between the wavelength of the electron and the circumference of its orbit that is used in the standing wave model.

(c) The circumference of the electron orbit can be calculated from the radius of the orbit found in part (a)(ii). Is the relationship between your values of the de Broglie wavelength from part (b)(i) and the circumference of the orbit consistent with your response in (b)(ii) ? Support your answer.
